A poundm UK-wide donation of food from Tesco has been helping a local foodbank support those unable to afford essentials during the Covid- pandemic. Foyle Foodbank has seen demand surge, with  families per month availing of its services over the last two months alone. With almost % of Foyle Foodbank’s stock coming from donations made in local supermarkets, the increase from Tesco is helping the food bank’s work. “Tesco’s food donations have helped us greatly, as they are sending essential items that we would run short of most of the year,” said the food bank’s manager James McMenamin. “In the past two months  families a month have been using our services, so these extra donations ensure we can distribute as many essential food packages as possible to the most vulnerable in our community.” googletag.cmd.push The food bank’s local Tesco store at Quayside Shopping Centre has donated over kg of food donations since the start of the year and over the last three weeks, over a tonne of extra food has been delivered. Tesco is donating the additional poundm of food to support partner charities FareShare and the Trussell Trust, of which Foyle Foodbank is a member.  Recent figures, released by the Trust, show an % rise in demand for food banks since the Covid- pandemic began. The Trust’s operations manager for Northern Ireland, Paul Armstrong, said they were grateful for Tesco’s support during the pandemic. googletag.cmd.push He said: “Food banks in our network acrossNorthern Irelandhave gone above and beyond to ensure they’re able to continue to provide the leline of emergency food. “These additional food donations from Tesco have helped to ensure people in financial crisis in Northern Ireland are able to access the emergency food and support they need during these challenging times.” Tesco’s Head of Community, Claire De Silva, said: “In every part of the UK there are charities and community groups doing amazing work to feed people during the pandemic, and we are glad that we have been able to support them in helping so many vulnerable people.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Churches across County Derry have released the times at which they will open for private prayer after the relaxation of the lockdown restrictions last week. The Northern Ireland Executive announced the move alongside measures that would also permit drive-in services to take place at churches. No churches have yet held a drive-in service, but Bishop Noel Traynor, speaking on behalf of the Irish Catholic Bishops’ Conference, welcomed ato private prayer. He said: “We warmly welcome this decision and I know it will bring tremendous consolation to all people of faith throughout the North of Ireland. “In the interest of public health and safety, during this first phase of reopening of churches, visits are for inidual, personal prayer and private devotions only. googletag.cmd.push “All visitors to churches must strictly observe the social distancing regulations and good hygienic practices outlined at Church entrances. “There is no obligation to visit Church and Mass will continue to be streamed privately via social media without a congregation present. A list of churches and their opening times can be found below: Swatragh Parish St John the Baptist will open from .am to .pm daily. Magilligan Parish St Aidan’s will be open from early morning until .pm daily. Maghera Parish Both St Patrick’s and St Mary’s are open from .am to .pm daily. Limavady Parish Times not confirmed as yet. googletag.cmd.push Lavey Parish St Mary’s Church of Our Lady of Mercy will open from .am to .pm daily. Kilrea Parish St Anne’s is open for private prayer from .am to .pm. Greenlough Parish St Oliver Plunkett Church will open .am to .pm Monday to Friday, .am to .pm on Saturdays and .pm to .pm on Sundays. Faughanvale Parish Star of the Sea and St Mary’s are both open .am to .pm daily. Dungiven Parish St Patrick’s will open .am to .pm daily. St Matthew’s Drumsurn and Immaculate Conception, Gortnahey are open . to .pm daily. Desertmartin Parish St Mary’s Coolcam is open .am to .pm Monday to Saturday and .pm to .pm on Sundays. Coleraine Parish St Malachy’s Church are currently consulting parishioners and hope to have an update by Sunday May . Claudy Parish Both St Patrick’s and St Joseph’s are open with no specied hours. Bellaghy Parish St Mary’s and St Joseph’s are open .am to .pm daily. Banagher Parish St Mary’s, St Peter’s and St Paul’s and St Joseph’s will open .am to .pm daily. Ballinascreen Parish Holy Rosary Church in Draperstown is open .am – .pm Monday to Saturday and .pm to .pm on Sundays. A Donegal soccer club has decided to donate the fee for entering this year’s Foyle Cup competition to charity. Cappry Rovers U-s - like a host of other young teams across Donegal - had entered the Foyle Cup in Derry, only for this summers tournament to be cancelled because of Covid-. Now the young players, coaches and parents have agreed to donate the € entry fee to the Donegal Hospice. Cora Harvey, who is Children’s Officer with Cappry Rovers FC, said it was a lovely gesture. “Obviously the young players and their coaches were really looking forward to the Foyle Cup,” she said. googletag.cmd.push “But it’s just one of those things. The tournament was cancelled and when their entry fee was ed, they decided it would be nice to donate it to charity.” The donation will be presented to the hospice, along with money raised in a virtual k fundraiser which Cappry Rovers are running this week.  The club normally hosts their annual k road race for the Joe Housten Cup on the June Bank Holiday weekend. But this year’s event was cancelled, and instead, the club is inviting people to check out their Facebook page for more details on their virtual k. Half of the proceeds raised will go to Donegal Hospice. googletag.cmd.push Anyone can take part in our Virtual k, Cora added. We have people entered from all over Donegal, and from Dublin and London too. Its just a bit of fun and its just € to enter. You can post your time when youre finished and half of the proceeds will go towards our club and the rest to Donegal Hospice. Full details of the fundraiser can be found on the Cappry Rovers Facebook page. The fundraiser started last Friday and will close at pm this coming Saturday, May . Counties need to look in the mirror to stop continued exodus to Australia, says former Kerry manager Eacuteamonn Fitzmaurice. In an extensive interview this weeks County Derry Post, the former Kingdom and Hogan Cup winning boss gives a Kerry slant to a feature on the minor clashes with Derry from  to . Derry have lost the services of Conor Glass and Callum Brown since minor level, with former U player Anton Tohill also lost to the AFL. Current Derry captain Chrissy McKaigue had a stint with Sydney Swans, and more recently Conleth McShane attended a AFL combine in Dublin before Christmas. googletag.cmd.push It was the same one Tohill and Oisin McWilliams attended two years ago. McWilliams later spent time in Australia with North Melbourne, in , but wasnt snapped up. Kerrys  goalkeeper Deividas Uosis and  winning captain Mark OConnor, both past pupils of Fitzmaurice have travelled down under, but their prize asset – David Clford – has stayed put. “It wasnt on his radar,” reveals Fitzmaurice of a meeting they had when he was senior manager. “He had no interest in going to Australia, or anywhere . Id say there were definitely approaches made but he wanted to play for Kerry and win All-Irelands with Kerry.” googletag.cmd.push On the flip side, Kerry lost OConnor to the AFL. He won two Hogan Cup medals under Fitzmaurice in Pobalscoil Chorca Dhuibhne. “He is a great guy and a big loss to Kerry,” Eacuteamonn states. “He got made an offer and decided to avail of it. From a Kerry perspective, it is up to us to make sure the players want to stay for the right reason. “If they do stay, they get a good education. There is a good job for them and they are well looked after to allow them to pursue an amateur sport. “Rather than giving out about it, it is always important to look in the mirror...is there anything we can do that would make a players le a bit easierthey do stay at home. David wanted to stay at home and we are delighted that he did.” Playing inter-county doesnt pay the bills, but Fitzmaurice sees a bigger picture. “When you are the manager of Kerry, thats what you want – for the players - to ensure the were happy in their personal and professional lives every bit as much as they are in their football lives. “If they are happy in their personal and professional lives, iniably they are going to be better footballers for it. Its not jobs for the boys, what you are trying to do is to encourage players to get a good education, to go down a route that they are interested in, so they can build a good career as well as being a successful footballer.” RELATED - Tohill waiting to make his mark. Derrys Matalan store is expected to reopen soon. The company has confirmed it has started to unfurlough some of its staff this week to prepare to reopen the majority of its six stores in Northern Ireland, including the store at a business park in the Waterside. Homeware was included in the list of businesses permitted to remain open under the legal restrictions which came into law in Northern Ireland on March . The regulations in England were subsequently updated on May  to include homeware as an essential business, prompting Matalan to begin a phased reopening of its English outlets. The company initially furloughed  staff in the north, but it has now confirmed that it will reopen its stores in Northern Ireland. googletag.cmd.push A Matalan spokesperson said:“Following the change in government guidance to include Homeware as essential retail on May st, Matalan, as a Clothing and Homeware Retailer with a signicant Homeware business,has been preparing carefully for asafe andphased re-opening stores, culminating in the successful re-opening of a select group of trial stores in England in recent weeks. Our priority is to protect both our colleagues and our customers’ safety in every store and we have received very positive comments from both colleagues, customers and regulatory bodieson the new safety measures in place in our stores. “Following this rigorousin-storetestingand consultation,we are now preparing to reopena number of our Northern Ireland stores and have started to unfurlough some of our staff to assist with the preparations. googletag.cmd.push Our new enhancedhealth andsafety measureswill ensure that every Matalan store which re-opens will be fully compliant with social distancing rules, withemployees trainedappropriatelyand provided withfull PPE.We are confident that these safety measuresare fully compliant with the guidance provided by the Northern Ireland Executive, UK Government and Department of Health. “In line withthelatestgovernment guidance,we plan on initially re-opening our spacious stores with large Homeware departments and a Click and Collect service. These stores are all located on out of town retail parks, with parking outside, enabling us to effectively adhere to social distancing guidelines.High street stores, stores in shopping centres, our clearance stores and our stores in Scotland and Wales will remain closed for now. “As we all start getting used to a new normal,we arereally looking forward to gradually welcoming our customers back into stores, and our colleagues ing from furlough. We areextremely grateful toall of our colleagues for their dedicatedeffortsin caringfor ourcustomersandthe business, andtoour customers for their continued loyaltyto Matalan.”  If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Former Derry City playerRuaidhri Higgins has been appointed to Stephen Kennys backroom team with the Republic of Ireland football set-up. Kenny has appointed Higgins, Damien Doyle and Kevin Mulholland to his backroom team as he continues to prepare for his first game in charge, the UEFA Nations League visit to Bulgaria in September.Higgins will take up the role of Senior National Team Chief Scout. A native of Limavady, Ruaidhri Higginsplayed for Stephen Kenny for five years at Derry City. He won the League as a player with Dundalk alongside Stephen in  and won it again as opposition analyst and coach in  and as assistant manager a year later. googletag.cmd.push Welcoming the appointments, Ireland manager Stephen Kenny said: “I’m delighted to welcome Ruaidhri, Damien and Kevin, they are great additions to the backroom team.
