title: top republicans gave identical written answers rhi inquiry wont say if they conferred
story: David McNarry: Unionists are not challenging Boris’s border betrayalThe PSNI set up road blocks to stop people going to the beach yet keep ignoring republican breaches of social distancingNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsPoliticsTop republicans gave identical written answers to RHI Inquiry – but won’t saythey conferredTwo senior republicans who played publicly unaccountable roles as Stormont fell in  provided identical answers to written questions from the RHI Inquiry, it can be revealed.By Sam McBrideThursday, th May , : am"" and Ted Howell are veteran senior republicans" "" width"" srcset" webimg TUFZMTIzNDQxMzUy.jpg crop:,smartwidth w,  webimg TUFZMTIzNDQxMzUy.jpg crop:,smartwidth w,  webimg TUFZMTIzNDQxMzUy.jpg crop:,smartwidth w" layout"intrinsic" and Ted Howell are veteran senior republicans" fallback"" layout"responsive" "" width"" src" img placeholder.png" class"i-amphtml-layout-responsive i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"responsive"Martin Lynchand Ted Howell are veteran senior republicansNew material published by the inquiry – which reported in March – includes witness statements from Ted Howell and Martin Lynch.The answers from the two men – the former of whom was trusted by the IRA as a go-between in the s and the latter of whom was Gerry Adams’ driver and described by Panorama’s John Ware as one of the IRA’s “most senior representatives” in  when he had a key role inhandling the Scappaticci informer aﬀair for the IRA – were word-for-word identical.The only discernible dference between the two statements was that Mr Howell used a slightly larger font size and Mr Howell’s was signed three days before that of his colleague. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The questions had been sent to Sinn Fein’s Connolly House headquarters in west Belfast but were addressed to each man personally.Last night Sinn Fein would not explain why their supposedly independent responses demonstrated such extraordinary similarities to each other, nor whether they had consulted with each other about what their evidence would be.The inquiry told most witnesses that they should not confer when responding to its questions and that the material given to them was to be treated in confidence. However, for some reason that warning was not included in the inquiry’s letter to the two men.For instance, in the written questions sent to former DUP minister Jonathan Bell he was told: “It is vital that the witness statement you provide to the inquiry is your own evidence, absent the influence of others ...”He was also told – as were many other witnesses – that “you may share the correspondence and the enclosed notice with your legal representative, but neither you nor they may show, communicate the contents of, nor provide this correspondence or the notice to any other person or organisation without the express permission of the RHI Inquiry. Any breach of this duty of confidentiality is actionable at the suit of the inquiry chairman”.Mr Bell, again in common with many witnesses, did not receive an offer to meet the solicitor to the inquiry, Patrick Butler.However, in his letters to Mr Howell and Mr Lynch, Mr Butler said: “If it would assist you, I am happy to meet with youto discuss the requirements of the Section  Notice and what evidence you may be able to provide which is within the scope of the Section  Notice.”By contrast to the identical evidence provided by Mr Howell and Mr Lynch, when Sinn Fein ‘super spad’ Aidan McAteer was asked some of the same questions, his answers were worded dferently – as were those of the spad to then finance minister Máirtín Ó Muilleoir, Eoin Rooney.The questions to all of the Sinn Fein figures had been around an Ofgem employee, Edd Fyffe, who had contacted Sinn Fein in January  and presented himself as a whistleblower, setting out a series of allegations against Ofgem, which runs RHI for Stormont.Each of the republicans said that they had handled his allegations appropriately and neither they nor Mr Fyffe were called to give oral evidence to the inquiry.The News Letter asked whether Mr Howell or Mr Lynch discussed with each other how they would respond to the inquiry and,not,how they could explain the remarkable similarity between their answers.At the time of going to press, there had been no response, despite repeated requests for comment.Mr Howell and Mr Lynch, along with veteran IRA man Padraic Wilson, had been the triumvirate of senior republicans to whom Mr Ó Muilleoir passed a series of complex policy decisions around RHI – even though none of them are energy experts, lawyers or serve as spads who are bound by civil service codes.Amid alarm from senior civil servants, Mr Ó Muilleoir had asked Mr Howell: “Would you be contentI were to sign off on the business plan on Wednesday afternoon ”The former finance minister insisted that he had been merely consulting the influential republican close to Gerry Adams and not seeking his consent to the plan for retrospective cost controls.However, the RHI Inquiry ruled that was not what had happened and Mr Ó Muilleoir had indeed asked for the publicly unaccountable republican’s consent for the massive decision.—— ——A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... story: Dinas Powys Voluntary Concern is working in partnership with Dinas Powys Medical Centre to send a letter from the charity to around  residents in the Dinas Powys and District who have been identied as having underlying health problems.They have been advised to stay at home for a duration of  weeks during which time they should shield themselves from physical contact with others.The letter gives information about the help and support that DPVC can offer and how to contact the DPVC Coordinators, Wendy and Judith for assistance with shopping, collecting and delivering prescriptions and telephone calls at regular intervals to ensure that they are safe andany help is needed.Cllr John Fanshaw said the charity was very busy throughout the community.He said: ldquoWe are still keen to offer further assistance. who remain dear to them.ldquoTo ensure that this can continue, we ask all visitors to take good care of themselves and others by observing current health guidance, including social distancing.ldquoWe must also ask that the grounds are not used for exercise or dog walking.ldquoPlease help us look after the cemetery by taking any waste materials home.ldquoPlease note that the toilets remain closed.ldquoFor health and safety reasons, it will be necessary for us to close the grounds during a funeral.ldquoIn current circumstances grounds maintenance has been scaled back and normal maintenance levels will resume when it is safe to do so.ldquoWe hope that reopening the cemetery brings comfort and thank you for supporting us in keeping yourself and others safe.The change comes after the Welsh Government introduced minor adjustments to the lockdown measures.The new rules allow people to exercise more than once a day near their home and enabled local authorities to begin the process of planning how to safely reopen libraries and municipal recycling centres.Garden centres are also allowed to reopen.Last week there were several incidents at the Merthyr Dyfan Cemetery in Barry which reopened on May .Barry Town Council received reports that visitors had not observed social distancing.On one occasion, a member of the public spat at a security guard whilst another coughed in a guardrsquos face.Signage stating that water and bins were not in use was ignored and strimmers and lawnmowers were brought to the burial ground.Barry Town Council is now reviewing the use of the centres.To begin with, only cars will be permitted access to the HWRC on Atlantic Trading Estate, Barry, and at Llandow.It will not be possible to provide access or appointment for trailers or vans at this time.Due to current demand, initially the council will be only be issuing one appointment slot per household, per month until further notice.Residents are asked to only make a bookingit is absolutely necessary, due to the sitesrsquo reduced capacity, and to arrive no earlier than five minutes before their allocated time to avoid any unnecessary queuing.The guidelines state that before visiting, residents must sort their waste or recycling appropriately to minimise the time at the site and residents must provide proof of residency eg driving licence or utility bill and display this in their windscreen while waiting to enter the site.Residents must follow on-site safety signs and guidance and residents should only exit their car when advised to do so by a member of site staff.Staff will be unable to provide assistance with lting or sorting so it is important to ensure all waste and recycling is manageable.Residents are also reminded thatthey do not respect social distancing or are abusive to staff they will be asked to leave site.It is important to remember that fly-tipping is a crime and leaving items outside the gates of a HWRC, on the street or in parks, woodlands and fields may result in a fixed penalty notice of up to pound being issued or even prosecution.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank residents for the assistance they have provided by storing items they wish to dispose of until now.ldquoUnfortunately, the period during which our household waste recycling centres were closed means there is now a backlog to clear, which is why we need a strict booking system until demand s to normal.ldquoWe appreciate this may cause some inconvenience but title: welsh government resilience plan supports education over s
story: The plan helps ensure that learners are supported throughout the coronavirus pandemic.It is aimed at education for learners aged  and over, including further and higher education, apprenticeships, employability and adult learning.The plan identies the priority groups most in need of support and sets out the expectations of how education providers and the Welsh Government will work together in response to covid- and how key decisions will be communicated.Since education providers in Wales closed for face-to-face learning on March , colleges and universities have moved to remote learning, delivering online lectures, tutorials and reviews, as well as ensuring support for more vulnerable learners continues.The plan is ided into three phases ndash the current lsquorescuersquo phase is focused on ensuring education providers have immediate security of funding and arrangements for learning in place this academic year the lsquoreviewrsquo phase plans for potential changes this autumn and the lsquorenewrsquo phase will put arrangements in place for the remainder of the academic year -.The plan identies learners for whom the coronavirus is likely to cause the most disruption, including Year  and , and vocational learners who need to access colleges or workplaces to complete their courses.The Welsh Government has increased online resources for post- through its Hwb , with distance learning resources available for both learners and providers.The Resilience Plan follows the publication of the continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, published last month.Education minister Kirsty Williams has also announced that pound.m of capital funding, part of the Secircr Cymru programme, will be used to invite applications from Welsh universities to submit novel research proposals that could contribute to or boost the advancement of research that impacts covid-.Ms Williams said: ldquoThe coronavirus has presented huge challenges for both students and education providers, in both the immediate and the longer term.ldquoThis Resilience Plan will provide a clear focus so we can work together with our education partners to overcome these challengesldquoThis plan will complement our continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, but recognises the greater levels of autonomy and ersity of education and training provided by the post- sector.ldquoOur colleges, universities and training providers are critical to the national response to the coronavirus and the rebuilding of the economy. We are committed to doing all we can to support them.Minister for economy, transport and North Wales, Ken Skates said: ldquoWe do not only want to bounce back from this pandemic, but to build back better by creating a national economy which sees employment, wealth and prosperity sp equally across Wales.ldquoThe post- education sector will be crucial to this.ldquoAs we shape our recovery from the impacts of coronavirus, we are committed to doing all we can to provide a strong foundation for those looking for employment, learners, trainees and apprentices to flourish in the future.ldquoThis incredibly challenging period has already highlighted the talent, commitment and incredible resilience of training and learning providers in supporting iniduals here in Wales.ldquoItrsquos efforts like these that will help ensure we emerge from this crisis stronger than ever. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new app provide specialist advice gps seconds

service, being rolled out across Wales, gives clinicians access to specialists in respiratory medicine, cardiology, diabetes, palliative care and acute medicine for covid.Health Boards can also add access to a range of local advice that is appropriate to their patientsrsquo needs.A GP or other clinician accesses the service either by dialling a phone number or using the Consultant Connect app.After choosing a speciality from a menu they are connected with a specialist in an average of  seconds.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am very pleased we are able to start rolling out the Consultant Connect in NHS Wales."This will help to support primary care to determine the right treatment for their patients.ldquoRight now it will save crucial time for health care professionals and reduce the story: BA said  job cuts were being considered in South Wales.The airline said it would act to try and protect as many jobs as possible.BAs parent company IAG has previously announced it was to cut , jobs from its , workforce.More storiesBritish Airways could cut  jobs at its Vale of Glamorgan maintenance baseThe proposals involve the Cardf Airport, Pontyclun and Blackwood site which employ maintenance and engineering staff. .Vale MS Jane Hutt said: "This is devastating news from BA which will affect highly skilled BAMC workforce and their families.ldquoThese workers are vital to the Welsh economy and to our communities.ldquoI will be backing and supporting them in every way I can.She added: ldquoI will be meeting with Minister Ken Skates MS, Unite the Union and BAMC workforce representatives today joining with Labour colleagues across South Wales.ldquoBAMC is part of our highly skilled Welsh aviation sector which must be supported at every level."South Wales Central Conservative AM, Andrew RT Davies said: "This is devastating news for the workers at the three British Airways sites in South Wales."I remember when the site was first developed in Rhoose and this BA maintenance facility now employees over  workers and is the key to production at other sites in Pontyclun and Blackwood."The aviation industry has taken a hammer blow due to coronavirus and hardworking people at BA in the region will be horribly hit by this news."These are high-skilled jobs which will not be easily replaced in our area and this reinforces the importance of getting the economy up and running once again."An economic tsunami is heading our way and this is only the first wave.ldquoWe need brave leadership at Westminster and Cardf Bay to ensure people have jobs toto."A British Airways spokesman said: ldquoWe are acting now to protect as many jobs possible.ldquoThe airline industry is facing the deepest structural change in its history, as well as facing a severely weakened global economy.ldquoWe are committed to consulting openly with our unions and our people as we prepare for a new future. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentIT was August  when a new reporter on the Penarth Times expressed surprise in one of his articles that such a progressive town as Penarth was without an operatic and dramatic society, writes Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Societypresident, Mary Gardner.The response to his outcry was quickly taken up and within three weeks the Penarth Operatic Society was formed.The Societyrsquos first production was Gilbert  Sullivanrsquos Iolanthe, played at The Hippodrome which later burnt down, and what a glittering opening evening it must have been as the audience wore evening dress.The review featured next day read, ldquoBrilliant Initial Performance.More newsVale council issues warning over the use of parksFines increased for coronavirus lockdown breachesMarie Curie Great Blooming Tea Party goes virtualA few years later in , the drama section came into being and with it a new title of the Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Society, known affectionately as PODS.Since then PODS has progressed down through the decades with many highlights along the way.One being in  when PODS presented that great musical, The King And I, which won the premier prize at the Waterford International Festival, for which the company received a beautul Waterford crystal vase.The Town Council held a reception to honour the Society at the Paget Rooms, and James Callaghan, the local MP, paid his tribute to PODS saying it ldquoadded lustre and brought culture to Penarth.Another landmark was the play, Dear Octopus, by Dodie Smith produced for PODS th anniversary celebrations.One of our most challenging and exciting shows was Cabaret in , which won the National Operatic  Dramatic Associationrsquos award for Best Production and Best Stage Management and Technical presentation.More recently in , to honour and pay tribute to the many men who gave their lives in World War One, PODS presented the very special play, Last Man Standing, which also won a NODA award for Best Drama.In , PODS decided to do pantomime, and this has been a greatly gratying and popular addition to the companyrsquos output.Itrsquos wonderful to see children in the cast having on-stage experience, and then those children in the audience, perhaps for the first time, enjoying and loving live theatre.PODS is a very busy Society putting on four shows a year, a musical, two plays and a pantomime.Mrs Gardner said: ldquoThis year, sadly and very upsettingly after much hard work by all involved, the covid- virus struck as PODS had just set-up at the Paget Rooms ready for its run of Goodnight Mister Tom, only to be told the venue would be shut down next day.ldquoSince January, the Society had also been rehearsing for its May musical, The Full Monty, and that too has had to be cancelled.       ,params: .pushldquoNevertheless, when this terrible emergency is over the company will put on these two productions sometime in the future. ldquoPODS is proud of its achievement in giving much pleasure and entertainment to the local community with its first-class shows over the last  years, and its goal is to make its centenary in  with the help of its faithful audiences, friends and patrons.PODS is always ready to welcome new members, but at the moment it cannot meet or rehearse due to the covid- restrictions.It might be some time before restrictions are lted on groups being able to rehearse together, or audiences allowed back in theatres, meanwhile PODS members keep in touch on social media.There is a lsquoPODS public grouprsquo on Facebook, PODS quiz nights are being held on Zoom, and there is a website to keep track at podspenarth.org article_url   content_id   site_id title: penarth esplanade sees surge visitors temperatures soar
story: Pictures and videos appeared on social media on Monday of groups of people sitting on the benches along the seafront, and groups of people gathering along the front.Currently, lockdown measures are still in place in Wales, and friends and families are not allowed to meet.More News:Tribute paid to Llandough Hospital nurse following her death from covid-Vale of Glamorgan Camera Club show Facebook their best spring picturesCoronavirus: New risk assessment in Wales for BAME peopleThe Welsh Government regulations state ldquoyou can only exercise alone or with a member of your household.South Wales Police did not discloseany people had been issued with a fine for breaking lockdown, but a spokesman said ldquoOur approach is to engage, explain and encourage people to follow the regulations.ldquoWe only apply [a Fixed Penalty Notice] as a last resort.ldquoItrsquos a matter for the inidual to ensure they follow the regulations.Some Penarth residents said they were concerned by the number of people along the seafront on Monday.Melanie Regan, , said she didnrsquot feel safe to walk along the seafront with her husband due to the number of people there.ldquoIt is so busy out there we donrsquot even walk out there, she said. ldquoThe bank holiday was packed, but it is not just the bank holidays.ldquoWith the amount of traffic and cars parked, itrsquos not just local people either.ldquoWe donrsquot feel safe going out there.Michelle Crow, from Penarth, said: ldquoWhile I was on my daily exercise walk with my dogs it felt like Windsor Road into Penarth was quite busy considering we are supposed to be in lockdown.However, other residents said the number of people at the seafront was not more than expected and everyone was following the guidance.Mary Taylor, from Penarth, said: ldquoWe were having our exercise along the promenade on Sunday.ldquoYes, most seats were occupied, there were people stood in between but on the whole they were appropriately socially distancing.ldquoMost car park spaces were full and there were some people on the beach so while I would agree that there were a lot out, it just wasnrsquot quite as bad as portrayed when we were there.Another Penarth resident, Andy Scott, said: ldquoAlthough people were out and about everybody was behaving themselves and adhered to Welsh Government guidelines on title: payouts made fewer  windrush compensation claimants
story: The Home Office said it has paid pound, to  people, including one payment in excess of pound,, during the first year of the scheme.The data add that , claims were made by the end of March this year, with the number received by the department decreasing each quarter since it launched. vw,vw,px, px"Home Secretary Priti Patel The compensation fund has an estimated budget of at least pound million, with the Home Office adding that it has also made offers of approximately pound, which have yet to be accepted.It said many people who have received compensation are likely to get more because what they have been given so far is an interim payment.MPs have previously warned there is a risk of people dying before they receive compensation owed unless the Government steps up its efforts.In , ministers faced a furious backlash over the treatment of the Windrush generation ndash named after a ship that brought migrants to Britain from the Caribbean in .Commonwealth citizens who arrived before  were automatically granted indefinite leave to remain.But some were later challenged over their immigration status despite living in the UK legally for decades.An independent review later found that the Windrush scandal was ldquoforeseeable and avoidable and victims were let down by ldquosystemic operational failings at the Home Office.Author Wendy Williams said the Government department had demonstrated ldquoinstitutional ignorance and thoughtlessness towards the issue of race and the history of the Windrush generation. vw, px"Data released by the Home Office showing the number of claims received under the Windrush compensation scheme Home Secretary Priti Patel, in a statement issued alongside the latest compensation data, said: ldquoBy listening to feedback from community leaders and those affected, we have begun to put right the wrongs caused to a generation who have contributed so much to our country.ldquoThe Windrush Compensation Scheme has been developed to ease the burden from the unacceptable mistreatment some have faced, which is why it is so important that people continue to come forward.Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran said the Government must ldquomake amends to those they hurt so much.She said: ldquoThe Prime Minister needs to come forward and make a fulsome apology, on behalf of the Government, to those who continue to be treated so shabbily during this sorry saga.The Windrush Compensation SchemeBill, which gives the Home Office the necessary parliamentary financial authority to make payments under the compensation scheme, has recently been approved by the Commons and Lords.The scheme was initially expected to be open for two years but the deadline for applications has been extended to April ..push,i[r].l*new title: some leisure activities set re open
story: Have you seen unlawfully at large Maurice Kane  -PSNI are asking him to hand himself inNI man dies in farm accidentNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsSome leisure activities set to re-openFollowing the Executive’s announcementthat COVID- restrictions are to be eased somewhat, Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council has provided further information about what it will mean for the borough’s leisure services.By The NewsroomFriday, nd May , : pm""The leisureservices impacted by the rule changes are golf, angling and tennis. The Council has also confirmed that car parks at parks and open spaces will be opening from Wednesday.The change to the leisure facilitiesare as follows:GolfGolf courses will reopen to members and subscribers from Saturday, May . The generalpublic will have access from Wednesday, May .Everyone hoping to play must book online in advance and golfers are not to arrive at the course more than  minutes in advance of their tee-off time. Rakes will be removed from the courses and golfers must not touch the flag or flag stick.For further information, Council advises residents to contact their local golf clubs directly.AnglingWith regards to angling, Council notes that angling facilities at Loughgall will reopen from Saturday, May .In line with Public Health Agency guideline, no sharing of fish positionsexcept by members of the same household is permitted nor is it allowed to share fishing tackle or other items. Anglers must stay two meters or more away from each other and on-sitetoilet facilities will remain closed.TennisThe Council’s tennis facilities will reopen to clubs only from Wednesday, May .Unless players are from the same household there will be a maximum of two people per court, players must only handle their own racket and ball, and players must avoid changing ends, or, make sure to change at opposite sides of the net.Club buildings and toilet facilitieswill remain closed and a buffer period of  minutes will apply between bookings.Car parksArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council has confirmed that car parks will reopen at Council’s parks and open spaces from Wednesday, May .It has also confirmed that due to reduced service levels currently operating, charging for entry into Gosford Forest Park and Loughgall is suspended until further notice.Council has also advised that despite car parks reopening at these facilities, access to public toilets, outdoor gyms and play parks is not permitted.Skateboard parks, caravan areas, park benches, mobile catering facilitiesand multi-use games areas are also off limits at present.For further information check the Council’s website.A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make of you.In order for us to continue to provide high quality and trusted local news on this free-to-read site, I am asking you to also please purchase a copy of our newspaper whenever you are able to do so.Our journalists are highly trained and our content is independently regulated by IPSO to some of the most rigorous standards in the world.But being your eyes and ears comes at a price. title: gortin glen forest amongst parks to reopen to public
story: The car park at Gortin Glen Forest Park is one of a number of council-owned open spaces which will reopen on Wednesday, May .Following a statement by the Minister for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs regarding the reopening of Forest Parks and the Public Angling Estate, and the easing of some restrictions announced recently by the Northern Ireland Executive car parks at Gortin Glen Forest Park, and at sites within the Marble Arch Caves UNESCO Global Geopark​ including Ely Lodge, Castle Archdale, Killykeegan, Lough Na and Castle Caldwell will reopen.Toilets, visitor amenities and play parks will remain closed at this time. No mobile food vendors will be permitted at the sites.In addition, the Council is reopening the following Still Water Loughs to angling from Wednesday, May .Drumacritten Lough Lough Acrussel Lough Barry Lough Inver Lough Lea Lough Nayre Lough Unshinagh and Lyons Lough.Killyfole Lough and Lough Eschleagh, which had previously been closed, reopened on Monday  May as part of DAERA’s Public Angling Estate.The chairperson of Fermanagh and Omagh District Council, Councillor Siobhaacuten Currie, in welcoming the move, sounded a note of caution. “While the Council welcomes the easing of some restrictions by the Executive which enables it to reopen these sites, the safety of users remains the underlying priority. The signs are encouraging, but we have not yet reached the stage in the battle against the spread of Covid- to lower our guard. I would encourage visitors to these areas to stay local, stay aware, adhere to existing social distancing protocols and respect the sites by taking litter home and leaving no trace.”The car parks and facilities at Gortin Glens and the sites within the Geopark, were closed to the public on  March while still water loughs were closed on  March following guidance from the Public Health Agency and the government applicable at that time.Marble Arch Caves Visitor Centre and Cuilcagh Mountain Boardwalk will remain closed to the public. Fermanagh and Omagh District Council will continue to actively review the status of its facilities in line with guidance from the NI Executive and with prevailing public health advice. The council will at all times put the health and safety of its residents, visitors and staff at the forefront of its decision making in relation to the reopening and the day to day operations of its
